title: 114_hr6157
content: The Act titled "Contact Lens Consumer Health Protection Act of 2016" aims to improve the contact lens prescriber verification process. The Fairness to Contact Lens Consumers Act is being amended to include a toll-free telephone number and email address for prescribers to contact with verification request questions. Prescribers can communicate concerns about prescription accuracy through these channels. The Fairness to Contact Lens Consumers Act is being amended to include a toll-free telephone number and email address for prescribers to verify prescription accuracy. Prescribers can inform sellers of inaccurate or expired prescriptions before a deadline, preventing the filling of invalid prescriptions. The Fairness to Contact Lens Consumers Act is being amended to include a toll-free telephone number and email address for prescribers to verify prescription accuracy. Prescribers can inform sellers of inaccurate or expired prescriptions before a deadline, preventing the filling of invalid prescriptions. Additionally, prescribers must specify the basis for inaccuracies, provide accurate prescriptions when questioned, and correct any inaccuracies communicated by the seller. Prescribers can request sellers to communicate verification requests through their preferred method of communication, such as live telephone, facsimile, or email. Sellers must offer these communication methods for prescribers to select from. Sellers must provide a toll-free telephone service and dedicated email address for prescribers to request verification of contact lens prescriptions. The amendments require sellers to offer a toll-free telephone service and dedicated email address for prescribers to verify contact lens prescriptions. The toll-free service must have live persons available to assist prescribers, and these changes will take effect 180 days after the enactment of the Act. Modification of prohibition on alteration of contact lens prescriptions. The Fairness to Contact Lens Consumers Act is amended to prohibit sellers from altering contact lens prescriptions. Sellers must dispense the prescription exactly as written by the prescriber, except in cases of private label contact lenses where the same lens is sold under multiple labels by the same company. This amendment will take effect 180 days after its enactment. The amendment to the Fairness to Contact Lens Consumers Act will take effect 180 days after its enactment. The Fairness to Contact Lens Consumers Act is amended to require sellers to maintain a database of prescriptions received, including issuance date and expiration date. Sellers must also keep copies of written notifications for at least 3 years. SEC. 5 prohibits advertising that suggests contact lens prescriptions can be filled after expiration. SEC. 6 increases penalties for sellers violating prescriber verification requirements. SEC. 7 amends the Fairness to Contact Lens Consumers Act by increasing fines for violations and clarifying its applicability to all contact lens sales in the U.S. A study on contact lens consumer compliance and safety is also mandated. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will conduct a study on violations of the Fairness to Contact Lens Consumers Act, focusing on prescription verification, business practices, and enforcement by the FTC. The study will address issues such as overfilling prescriptions, dispensing expired or inaccurate prescriptions, and failure to allow prescribers to contact sellers. The study will address issues such as overfilling prescriptions, dispensing expired or inaccurate prescriptions, failure to allow prescribers to contact sellers, health and economic risks to consumers, improper advertising about valid prescriptions, and other health effects from violations of the Fairness to Contact Lens Consumers Act. The Secretary will submit a report to Congress and the Federal Trade Commission within 1 year of the enactment of the Act, addressing issues related to the Fairness to Contact Lens Consumers Act. SEC. 8. MODIFICATION OF DEFINITIONS. In the Fairness to Contact Lens Consumers Act, Section 11 is amended to include definitions for "business hour" and "business day." Business hour is defined as any hour between 9:00 AM and 5:00 PM in the prescriber's time zone, while business day excludes Saturdays, Sundays, and legal holidays. These amendments will take effect 180 days after the date of enactment. The amendments in the Fairness to Contact Lens Consumers Act will take effect 180 days after enactment.
